title: Texas moves to cut off Planned Parenthood from Medicaid funds

Post to Facebook Texas moves to cut off Planned Parenthood from Medicaid funds Texas has decided to cut off Medicaid funding to Planned Parenthood clinics following the release of controversial videos.  //kvue.tv/1LGrO5b   Texas moves to cut off Planned Parenthood from Medicaid funds KVUE 11:38 a.m. CDT October 19, 2015 Sign outside of Planned Parenthood in San Antonio (Photo: KENS 5) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
HOUSTON – Texas has decided to cut off Medicaid funding to Planned Parenthood clinics following the release of controversial videos recorded earlier this year of officials discussing fetal tissue. 
In a letter from the Texas Health and Human Services Commission, the state alleged that Planned Parenthood “committed and condoned numerous acts of misconduct captured on video that reveal repeated program violations and breach the minimum standards of care required of a Medicaid enrollee.” 
No charges of criminal wrongdoing have been brought against Planned Parenthood of Texas regarding anything contained in the videos released by the anti-abortion group, Center for Medical Progress. 
The state said in the letter, which you can read in full below, the videos “indicate that you follow a policy of agreeing to procure fetal tissue even if it means altering the timing or method of an abortion. These practices violate accepted medical standards, as reflected in federal law, and are Medicaid program violations that justify termination.” 
The state also wrote in the letter that Planned Parenthood “failed to prevent conditions that would allow the spread of infectious disease among employees, as well as patients, and the general public.” It also said, “your staff were not trained in infection control and barrier precautions with regard to the handling of fetal blood and tissue or they failed to comply with the minimum standards that mandatory training requires…” 
The Health and Human Services Commission said it had a “prima facie case of fraud” against Planned Parenthood based on “whistleblower” cases with claims alleged in federal court, specifically Reynolds vs. Planned Parenthood Gulf Coast; and Carroll vs. Planned Parenthood Gulf Coast. 
In the Reynolds case, Texas stated that the whistleblower “alleged sufficient evidence of fraud to assure the federal court handling the matter that the case was worth pursuing, after which Planned Parenthood promptly settled the lawsuit for $4.3 million.” 
In the letter, the state told Planned Parenthood, “Your termination and that of all your affiliates will not affect access to care in this State because there are thousands of alternative providers in Texas, including federally qualified health centers, Medicaid-certified rural health clinics, and other health care providers across the State that participate in Texas Women’s Health Program and Medicaid.” 
Texas Governor Greg Abbott released a statement Monday about the move that read in part, ““The gruesome harvesting of baby body parts by Planned Parenthood will not be allowed in Texas and the barbaric practice must be brought to an end.” 
The move by the state of Texas could trigger a legal battle similar to the one currently going on in Louisiana. Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal ordered his state to block funding in the wake of the same videos. 
Planned Parenthood in Louisiana has challenged the state’s right to end funding for cancer screenings, ob/gyn exams, and other health services. On Monday, a federal judge ordered Louisiana to continue providing Medicaid funding to Planned Parenthood clinics for 14 more days. Read or Share this story: http://kvue.tv/1LGrO5b TOP VIDEOS
